article.title: Hot Leptogenesis from Thermal Dark Matter

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 illustrates how the ratio of the temperature of the right-handed neutrino N1 to the Standard Model sector temperature (κ1) changes over time for three different scenarios. Which scenario shows κ1 remaining constant until N1 becomes non-relativistic and then decays?
choices: Scenario (i) with N2 and N3 much heavier than the dark sector temperature (T\').
Scenario (ii) with N2 lighter than the dark sector temperature (T\').
Scenario (iii) with both N2 and N3 lighter than the dark sector temperature (T\').
None of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 compares the rates of different processes involving dark matter (DM) and right-handed neutrinos (RHNs) as functions of z\' (the ratio of DM mass to dark sector temperature). Which process is represented by the green solid line and generally dominates at early times, even with a small mass splitting?
choices: DM annihilation (Γann).
RHN scattering with SM particles (Γscatt).
RHN oscillation (Γosc).
Hubble expansion rate (H).

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 shows the decoherence conditions for right-handed neutrinos (RHNs) as functions of z\'.  What do the magenta dotted line (d(a)) and purple dashed line (d(b)) represent?
choices: d(a) represents the energy uncertainty compared to RHN mass splitting, while d(b) represents the wavepacket separation compared to RHN scattering timescale.
d(a) represents the RHN oscillation rate, while d(b) represents the RHN scattering rate.
d(a) represents the Hubble expansion rate, while d(b) represents the DM annihilation rate.
d(a) represents the RHN decay rate, while d(b) represents the inverse decay rate.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 shows the parameter space yielding the observed DM relic abundance. What is the meaning of the light orange bands in this figure?
choices: Regions where the DM is relativistic at freeze-out.
Regions excluded due to violation of various bounds imposed on the model.
Regions where leptogenesis is successful.
Regions where the dark sector temperature is lower than the SM temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 depicts the efficiency factor (η) as a function of the DM mass (MX). What happens when η is close to 1?
choices: The DM annihilation cross section needed is significantly larger than the thermal cross section.
The DM annihilation cross section needed is close to the typical thermal cross section.
Leptogenesis cannot be successful.
The dark sector temperature is much lower than the SM temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 6 displays the parameter space for scenario (i) where N2 and N3 are very heavy. What do the blue and grey regions represent in this figure?
choices: Blue regions correspond to successful leptogenesis with Td < TEWsp, while grey regions correspond to Td > TEWsp.
Blue regions correspond to successful leptogenesis with Td > TEWsp, while grey regions correspond to Td < TEWsp.
Blue regions correspond to normal neutrino mass ordering, while grey regions correspond to inverted neutrino mass ordering.
Blue regions correspond to cases where RHNs are in thermal equilibrium with the SM, while grey regions correspond to cases where they are not.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7 shows the efficiency (η) as a function of the DM mass (MX) and the effective neutrino mass (m˜1). What is the significance of the right plot in this figure?
choices: It shows the maximum allowed value of m˜1 for various κ1 before the dark and SM sectors thermalize.
It shows the minimum allowed value of MX for successful leptogenesis.
It shows the mass splitting needed for successful resonant leptogenesis.
It shows the range of DM annihilation cross sections compatible with the observed DM abundance.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figures 8 and 9 show the parameter space for scenarios (ii) and (iii), respectively. What distinguishes these scenarios from scenario (i)?
choices: In these scenarios, N2 and/or N3 are lighter than the DM mass, unlike scenario (i) where they are much heavier.
These scenarios do not require resonant enhancement for leptogenesis, unlike scenario (i).
These scenarios predict a DM annihilation cross section that is always larger than the thermal cross section, unlike scenario (i).
These scenarios cannot be tested by indirect detection experiments, unlike scenario (i).

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 10 illustrates the mass splitting (δ2) between the two lightest RHNs as a function of the DM mass (MX) for scenarios (ii) and (iii). Why is this mass splitting important?
choices: It determines the DM annihilation cross section.
It determines the efficiency of leptogenesis (η).
It determines whether decoherence is efficient enough to prevent RHN thermalization with the SM.
It determines the decay temperature of the RHNs.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 11 compares the upper limits on the thermally averaged DM annihilation cross section with the parameter space for observed DM relic abundance. What do the blue and orange lines represent in this figure?
choices: Blue lines represent limits from Fermi-LAT and H.E.S.S., while orange lines represent limits from CTA.
Blue lines represent limits from Fermi-LAT and MAGIC, while orange lines represent limits from H.E.S.S..
Blue lines represent limits for normal neutrino mass ordering, while orange lines represent limits for inverted neutrino mass ordering.
Blue lines represent limits for scenario (i), while orange lines represent limits for scenarios (ii) and (iii).

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 12 compares the upper limits on the DM annihilation cross section with the parameter space for scenarios (i), (ii), and (iii). What is the main takeaway from this figure?
choices: These scenarios cannot be tested by indirect detection experiments.
These scenarios predict a DM annihilation cross section that is always smaller than the thermal cross section.
These scenarios predict an enhancement in the DM annihilation cross section compared to the thermal value, bounded by a factor of max(η).
These scenarios are already ruled out by current observations.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (2.31) defines the efficiency factor (η) for hot leptogenesis. What does this factor quantify?
choices: The strength of the CP violation in RHN decays.
The gain in RHN abundance due to a hotter dark sector compared to the dilution due to late decays of hot RHNs.
The temperature ratio between the dark and SM sectors.
The mass splitting between the lightest and heaviest RHNs.
